title: Ashe rework initially very impressive, but is really simple in actuality
body:
While flurried arrows look cool, and the new crit system is an interesting way to scale with crit, I feel like the essential gameplay of her new mechanics are still very simple.

Her new crits are basically a different way to apply very similar overall damage.  She still has her passive slow, and 3 of her skills are essentially unchanged.

The only they they really added was her Empowered Focus shots.  While it looks fancy, it really is just a glorified steroid (albeit a strong one).

Once you have enough stacks, press button for more AD, AS, and slowing power.


This isn't a bad thing.  In fact, I applaud Riot for keeping her simple.  Newbie friendly champions are becoming a smaller and smaller part of the champion list, and reworks bring a danger of overcomplicating champions.

Once I realized how simple her new mechanics are though, my initial hype sort of died a bit.

replies.body:
tl;dr ashe rework
99% right clicking

tl;dr every adc ever
99% right clicking
Aside from Ez, if you aren't furiously right clicking your way to victory as any of those manly men, you're probably dead.
If you have to furiously right click as Graves, you're not bursting right.
Same with Corki and Lucian. Lucian's the most right-clicky one of those 4, and that's still not nearly enough to properly do damage as him.
Like Corki is ever in range to AA unless he's already won or lost the team fight LOL
Every Corki I've ever seen that hard carried wasn't afraid to get up close and personal.

I just saw a video that showed how Runaan's works with her new Q and it is legitimately one of the coolest (heh) item synergies in the game. Each bolt of her focus empowered attacks triggers runaan's passive now, so she fires 10 bolts *every single AA* each bolt applies The Black Cleaver's armor shred, so in one single shot she can shred 3-5 enemy champions' armor by 30%.

They also buffed back her W damage again today.

The changes are simple for anyone who uses her the same way as before (she keeps a relatively low skill floor, meaning she is easy to play) but open up ways for more skilled players to pull of really crazy stuff now (they've buffed her skillcap essentially).
upvote for the pun
Yeah. I outduled a Kali today with the new Ashe. I am happy now.

I'm not a fan of newbie champs as a concept in general. I don't think that means that every champ needs a bunch of skill shots and hard-to-counter combos, but I'm also not a fan of champs that have no chance of ever seeing serious competitive play (say Plat and Diamond at least, if not esports level). That feels like a broken contract with players who pick up, purchase or fall in love with a particular main.

However, what I do like about the Ashe changes is that they were relatively straight forward, easy to understand, don't change her into something unrecognizable, but should still make her a little cooler (lol), while giving her more depth. Let use know how it works.

I think it is important to distinguish champions with a low skill floor from ones who have a low skill ceiling. Champions with a low skill floor are newbie friendly and are inarguably vital for the health of the new player experience. This is vital for maintaining league as a primer game and it is one way in which (imo) league is suffering right now. Champions with a low skill ceiling have the where when you perform their combos perfectly, they don't send chills (puns) down the spine of the enemies because they don't have the impact that other champions have if played well. This is of course a separate problem worth considering, but it's important not to overlook the new player experience in the process.

What are your thoughts on champions with a low vs. high skill floor?
there are plenty of champions with low skill floors that are used in the lcs {{champion:238}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:127}} {{champion:89}} {{champion:102}}  list goes on

Yeah, they are played but they also by and large have a high win rate due to their relative safety. I guess my question could be re-framed into ...

How do you balance having champions with a low skill floors with champions who have high skill ceilings and how do you go about balancing champions so they are viable in high level play while still viable to pick up for the casual first time moba player?

In my opinion in order for a champ to be good for pros/noobs it needs to have skillshots, and those skillshots need to have interaction with other things.

For example, take a look at Neith. The Noob's ADC with an autoaim ult. However, she has a  counterplay to her ult (teammate body blocks it) and interaction with her skillshots, which could allow fun gameplay for both pros and noobs.

Newbie champs in League has been implemented and updated pretty well over time.  A champion being newbie friendly doesn't automatically mean they won't be played at high elos or competitively.  Just look at Annie.

Heck, even pre-rework Ashe had a moment in the spotlight when Sneaky and Lemonnation ran Ashe+Zyra and demolished the competition with it.  Pre-nerf Ryze also had several stretches of time as a top tier pick.  A champion being newbie friendly in League has very little effect on the champ's competitive viability.
I was so scared that you guys were gonna give her a dash + ult knock up etc, glad to see her core uniqueness intact :)

You've made a statement, and I'm paraphrasing and interpreting it differently, that you don't consider LoL to be a newb-friendly game. That what attracts you to it is how competitive players handle the gameplay. If I were a new player, how would/should I learn the game if you had the chance to redesign it from scratch?

I dunno, it's just after reading what her Q really does, it felt kinda underwhelming. I mean, with all the limitations put on it, it just feels like a weaker more sustained version of draven's Q.

Honestly, it really feels like riot is scared of making really cool abilities that can actually synergize with on-hit effects.

I mean, is it too much to ask for a champ to be able to be viable using an atkspd on-hit proc build? Right now, we only have teemo, kayle, and kog, and they are only okay with those types of builds cuz they already have strong steriods and can benefit from the ap on nashors.

Would it be too much to ask to actually be capable of having a multi-hit ability/steroid so that buying Wit's End {{item:3091}}  doesn't feel like a waste of gold?

I really love the concept of atkspd builds and would really appreciate it if riot would fully support that build path with more/better items and champs that can fully make use of them.

When I first saw that the new ashe Q fired off 5 shots, I was really excited to try an atkspd build on her, only to be immediately let down that she only procs on-hits once. :(
Well there was that Warwick ult + Challenging smite + devourer....
yeah, on hit builds tend to be problematic.

It is almost certainly because it would be impossible to balance. Take Ashe as an example. Buy a BotRK and a Runaan's. If on hit effects work as you would like then Ashe could take away (before resistances) over 35% of three of the enemy's HP in one attack. With only two items. This is not factoring in her AD. This is undoutably bulllshit given how many of the empowered attacks she gets.

The long and the short is that the items in LoL are balanced for cases where they are only procced once each attack. For this type of thing to be balanced you would have to lower the power of on hit effects quite drastically, making them useless for most champions who love them at the moment.

{{champion:19}}  + {{item:3718}}   Never forget

honestly, I didn't mind ww being able to build that and do well with it. Was he frustrating to play against? yes. but for more reasons that just super atkspd on-hit procs with his ult.

ww was able to not only do well with that build path, but also do everything else as well. He had tremendous sustain, great dmg and steroids, and could solo dragon any time he wished. If we could rewind time back when ww had his oh so OP devourer but we gutted his sustain instead, he'd have not been nearly as egregious. But the problem there lies in the fact that sustain is part of ww's identity, so we were at a catch-22.

> [{quoted}](name=Ghostcrawler,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=0015,timestamp=2015-04-30T18:42:00.899+0000)

I don't think that means that every champ needs a bunch of skill shots and hard-to-counter combos, but I'm also not a fan of champs that have no chance of ever seeing serious competitive play (say Plat and Diamond at least, if not esports level). That feels like a broken contract with players who pick up, purchase or fall in love with a particular main.
> 
> However, what I do like about the Ashe changes is that they were relatively straight forward, easy to understand, don't change her into something unrecognizable, but should still make her a little cooler (lol), while giving her more depth. Let use know how it works.

Newbie champions (those lacking skill shots / hard to counter combos) can still be competitively viable in that it takes mastery to optimize them. Ryze and Sona are such examples and Udyr in niche comps. They rely on knowing when to activate their combos and in which order -- which is something that is sorely lacking now with the changes to Ryze. I hope in the future we can get more "combo" characters that don't have skill shots just because the game is becoming a huge skill shot fest above everything else.
what do u think as annie as a newbie champ she use a lot?

So nobody's going to mention the global Hawkshots? I always thought that was going to be a big improvement. Losing the passive extra gold was worth it, in my opinion. Not to mention the fact that it still shows vision for the entire pathway, so you can throw it in the enemy jungle and have a good shot at finding the jungler, which will relieve pressure on the map.
So? If anything, that makes me like it more; no need to entirely relearn the champion.

I don't really see a problem. Ashe needed changes, and these will definitely be good for her.
Her old passive was useless on and ADC aside from initial burst, and was replaced by her Q permaslow and new crit mechanic
Her old Q was moved to her passive and her new Q is simple, yeah, but it applies on-hit effects and will make her build path interesting
W was unchanged for the most part but you can hit a minion wave and instantly get 5 stacks of focus
E dropped the passive gold for 2 shots of global vision, which is well worth it
Ult unchanged

plus, the new {{item:3071}} will have great synergy with her Q and will help her kite even more

It's not just a glorified steroid. It really does hit 5 times. This allows you to shoot 10 runaan bolts per auto, and apply 5 black cleaver stacks per auto.
This has some srs implications

A red confirmed that Runaan's only procs twice per Flurry shot.  While this makes Ashe synergize with Runaan's better than most other ADCs, I feel like it simply won't be enough.  Runaan's works on Kalista because it stacks Rend on multiple targets and it boosts her mobility.

On Ashe, the bolts basically do their normal damage.  It gives stronger multi-target damage for a short time, but I feel as though Runaan's is weak enough that it would still be a subpar choice compared to the standard crit build.

Black Cleaver suffers the same fate.  Its damage output is simply outstripped by the standard ADC items.

> [{quoted}](name=Felixphaeton,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-04-29T22:39:25.394+0000)
>
> A red confirmed that Runaan's only procs twice per Flurry shot.  While this makes Ashe synergize with Runaan's better than most other ADCs, I feel like it simply won't be enough.  Runaan's works on Kalista because it stacks Rend on multiple targets and it boosts her mobility.

Runaan's goes out 5 times (10 total bonus shots), but deals reduced damage per extra shot.

This means that it'll stack TBC shred on multiple targets insanely quickly.

Quote in question:
"Runaan's fires 2 bolts for **every single attack during a Focus-empowered Q**. It feels pretty cool."

:information:

Do you really need {{item:3035}} if you already have {{item:3071}}?  Sure it would be nice, but NEED it?

Obviously the waveclear of {{item:3087}} is pretty redundant in any build with {{item:3085}}.  So you're probably going to build {{item:3046}} for raw stats instead.

But an onhit build isn't going to be viable unless you can actually compete with crit, so you *don't* need {{item:3031}} and another crit item in every single game on every single bot laner ever.

Champions who don't naturally want to build this way just don't get played at all, like {{champion:21}} {{champion:110}}, {{champion:29}} outside of a few stealth-focused strats, and these days even {{champion:67}}.  Let alone the mere idea of {{champion:17}} having a viable AA build -- you'd probably be reported if you tried it right now.

There are already {{item:3031}} steroid/autoattacker marksmen and {{item:3078}} ranged AD caster marksmen -- can't they be balanced against {{item:3085}} poison/blight/impurify all the things marksmen?  (If not, there are a whole lot of people in need of reworks.)  Even if Ashe ultimately falls into the steroid camp, or has the option to go either way, there should actually *be* multiple choices.

> [{quoted}](name=Joquan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=0000000000000001,timestamp=2015-04-30T19:25:50.253+0000)

Yes we/I can.

I can build whatever the hell I want.

I was thinking Lucid/Zerks; IE; TBC; PD; ER/BT; LW/Other

I mean, honestly, let me quote a motto from the US Marine Corps:

"If it's stupid but it works, it ain't stupid."

I build Ahri with a Rod of Ages and a Nashor's Tooth and regularly win with this-- just as much as I win building a more typical Luden's and such.

I do the same with Ezreal; I build no defensive items on him and instead rely on the build of Lucidity/TF/ER/BT/Manamune to keep me safe and out of the fight (Lucidity, TF, ER, and Tear are very conducive to this; BT gives sustain) until I can clean up by going in with the devastating basics that I have not optimized for; and I finish this with an IE so that those basics are properly devastating.

:/

You're also unranked. 

You shouldn't act like your builds are actually good and resonable for everyone.

Any reasonable player should be able to stomp you with those shitty builds.

> [{quoted}](name=Joquan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=000000000000000100010000,timestamp=2015-05-04T17:50:15.396+0000)
>
> You're also unranked. 

Literally meaningless.

MMR and rank are completely unrelated-- you can play against anybody near your MMR in Normals.

:/ My Normals mmr is kind of high. It'd be higher but I don't play to win every game, I just play who I want to play and do my best with that pick.

> You shouldn't act like your builds are actually good and resonable for everyone.

Well... they're good builds if they win, right?

They're reasonable if others succeed with them, right?

All of my builds-- and I help my friends with -original- builds all the time, so including those--

They *work*. They win just as well as normal ones.

Particularly that Ezreal build, I told my friends to go with that and over the course of 6 games they were 90/15/65 or so.

'If it's stupid, but it works, it ain't stupid.'

I do actually take down evidence that my builds aren't stupid because of how many wacky things I do.

Some of them ARE stupid. 
(Triforce-Spirit Visage Yasuo, back when he came out and was more defensive, for example; didn't work.)

> Any reasonable player should be able to stomp you with those shitty builds.

Then I guess, since my opponents are reasonable players, that the builds aren't that bad.

Try it some time. You'd... be a bit surprised what works. :/

this is what I'm talking about.

Your rank DOES matter if your talking about what wins stuff. 
You're builds are perfectly acceptable in your normal games. Do whatever you want to win no one cares.

I play ranked, not normals. I don't play for fun, I play  to win while having fun with the most effective tools I have at my disposal.

I'm just saying that  as you play ranked the kind of stuff you're doing will stop working at probably silver and for sure at gold 4+

Keep in mind you're playing normals. Not everyone is trying as hard as you, and don't care if they lose to your builds.

Just remember in ranked you're eventually gonna have to stop those awful builds my friend, but in normals do whatever the hell you want. Hell even build that shit in ranked, you certainly won't go far with that. 
Checking at your na.op you're losing to people both unranked and in bronze. I don't think you'll make it to higher silver ( no offense )

When you want to climb lolking and teamsolomid are waiting with good builds (usually) for you.

BTW  just because you're playing with people "high" ranked in normals doesn't matter. 

Normals have diffrent MMR than rank.

Once again just remember I'm trying to go for the best way possible because I'm a ranked player. Keep having fun man, just know if you do that crap in ranked you won't go far

> [{quoted}](name=Joquan,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=00000000000000010001000000000000,timestamp=2015-05-04T22:52:41.938+0000)
>
> this is what I'm talking about.
> 
> Your rank DOES matter if your talking about what wins stuff. 
> You're builds are perfectly acceptable in your normal games. Do whatever you want to win no one cares.

Rank doesn't matter because the important metric is MMR, e.g. how good you and your opponents are, how much game sense they have.

> I play ranked, not normals. I don't play for fun, I play  to win while having fun with the most effective tools I have at my disposal.

And my point was that the builds work even at higher ranks. If they hadn't, I would have tried harder to imply that they don't.

> I'm just saying that  as you play ranked the kind of stuff you're doing will stop working at probably silver and for sure at gold 4+

I honestly doubt it.

> Keep in mind you're playing normals. Not everyone is trying as hard as you, and don't care if they lose to your builds.

Except I don't "try" at *all* in my games. I just have fun.

> Just remember in ranked you're eventually gonna have to stop those awful builds my friend, but in normals do whatever the hell you want. Hell even build that shit in ranked, you certainly won't go far with that. 

I've had my friends do it. In gold.

They, and I, have a 100% ranked winrate with them.

At least, last time I checked. Admittedly I haven't checked in a while.

> Checking at your na.op you're losing to people both unranked and in bronze. 

Of course I do. I don't play somebody unless I want to play them.

I value having fun during a game over winning.

So I don't play ranked games, because I know a number of people actually prefer seeing their numbers go up.

So I don't play really hard, because then I can relax more.

>I don't think you'll make it to higher silver ( no offense )

Well it'd be hard to get into a higher Silver than Silver 1; which is where I got placed last time I actually did ranked games.

> When you want to climb lolking and teamsolomid are waiting with good builds (usually) for you.

Nope.
I'll stick to making my own builds, even when I get to playing ranked games.

Because... making the builds is part of the fun.

> BTW  just because you're playing with people "high" ranked in normals doesn't matter. 

Well, it's good I wasn't talking about those games when I gave my examples.

I was talking about making my friends play using my build, not play *with me*.

> Once again just remember I'm trying to go for the best way possible because I'm a ranked player. 

And I'm saying-- and all I've been trying to say-- is that there are a lot of things that work that one may not think work at first.

>Keep having fun man, I'm not trying to call you shit, just your builds :)

My builds are unique and fun-- and **win**.

They can't be "shit" as you've described them twice if they are effective and win games on a semiregular basis, right? I mean, if a build has a 50% winrate, that's **expected**, so what about a ~60%?

Admittedly that's the average across a whole bunch of builds that I've made, but it is somewhat a relevant number... right?

According to your na.op.gg you were season 4 bronze. Lolking says your season 4 bronze. Nice try bud.


Just because your friend stomps noobs doesn't mean your crap is good. It just means hes smurfing or he seriously outskilled his opponents. On equal skill levels you're going to lose 100% as an ADC with no last whisperer (looking at your jinx game... lol)
Look, enjoy it and all, i'm done wasting my time.
I don't give a fuck about you winning normals. They are NORMALS. You're unranked, you're winning literally means nothing. It is a gamemode for fun and fun only, so your builds don't matter.
Good luck getting into gold with those shitty builds.

> [{quoted}](name=Felixphaeton,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IfvQhGce,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2015-04-29T22:39:25.394+0000)
>
> A red confirmed that Runaan's only procs twice per Flurry shot.  While this makes Ashe synergize with Runaan's better than most other ADCs, I feel like it simply won't be enough.  Runaan's works on Kalista because it stacks Rend on multiple targets and it boosts her mobility.
> 
> On Ashe, the bolts basically do their normal damage.  It gives stronger multi-target damage for a short time, but I feel as though Runaan's is weak enough that it would still be a subpar choice compared to the standard crit build.
> 
> Black Cleaver suffers the same fate.  Its damage output is simply outstripped by the standard ADC items.

Ummmm, it gives her Auto-Attacks an AoE slow...I'm not sure why you think it isn't good...

Think of it, AoE slow + increased damage against slowed targets which dodges Runaan's bolt crit rule
I don't think you realized how good this is... Build BT, IE, and RH for slows and damage for days.
Whats wrong with that? She has always been a simple character.
So her kit was improved and she kept her simplicity? That seems good to me.

The only thing that really changed was:

* Another damage output ability.
* Another Hawkshot charge. (And global range)
* More arrows coming out of Volley.

All of which are 110% buffs to her.

> 110%

I see what you did there

Meh, the Volley changes are actually kind of a nerf since its easier for minions to block.

I'm just happy she actually has a steroid now. And a damage steroid on top of a speed steroid!

It's hard to say since I haven't played it personally, but I think more arrows out of Volley is actually a nerf, because of the way they changed the mechanics. More arrows are more likely to hit the same target without dealing extra damage. So it's going to be harder to hit enemies past a minion wave, which is usually your intended target.
